revision.text:
'''Documentary theatre''' is theatre that uses pre-existing [[documentary]] material (such as [[Newspaper|newspapers]], government reports, [[Interview|interviews]], journals, and correspondences) as source material for stories about real events and people, frequently without altering the text in performance. The genre typically includes or is referred to as '''verbatim theatre''', '''investigative theatre''', '''theatre of fact''', '''theatre of witness''', '''autobiographical theatre''', and '''ethnodrama'''.<ref>Martin, Carol. ''Theatre of the Real''. Palgrave Macmillan, 2013, p. 5.</ref>
==History==
=== Zhivaya Gazeta and Piscator === While fact-based drama has been traced back to Ancient Greece and [[Phrynichus (tragic poet)|Phrynichus]]' production of ''The Capture of Miletus in'' 492 BC<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kjZaAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y|title=Voicings: Ten Plays from the Documentary Theatre|last=Favorini|first=Attilio|date=1995|publisher=Ecco Press|isbn=9780880013970|language=en}}</ref>, contemporary documentary theatre is rooted in theatrical practices developed in [[Eastern Europe]] during the 1920s and 1930s. In the years after the [[Russian Revolution]], the USSR's Department of Agitation and Propaganda employed theatre troupes known as the Blue Blouses<ref>"Documentary drama and theatre." ''The Oxford Companion to Theatre and Performance.'' 2010, p. 173.</ref> (so called because they wore factory workers' overalls) to stage current events for a largely illiterate population.<ref>Senelick, Laurence, and Ostrovsky, Sergei. ''The Soviet Theater: A Documentary History''. Yale University Press, 2014. 3 April 2018 <<nowiki>http://www.myilibrary.com?ID=614054</nowiki>></ref> The [[Blue Blouse|Blue Blouses]] dramatized news items and current events through song, dance, and staging, and by 1924 these performances were standardized into the form of the ''zhivaya gazeta'' or living newspaper.<ref>Innes, C.D. ''Erwin Piscator's Political Theatre: The Development of Modern German Drama''. CUP Archive, 1972, pp. 24</ref>
Meanwhile, in Germany, [[Erwin Piscator]] was experimenting with incorporating documentary film footage and other primary source material into his "mass spectacles"<ref name=":0">Irmer, Thomas. “A Search for New Realities: Documentary Theatre in Germany.” ''TDR The Drama Review'', vol. 50, no. 3, 2006, pp. 16–28. ''JSTOR'', JSTOR, www.jstor.org/stable/4492692.</ref> and in 1925 wrote ''In Spite of Everything'', a piece derived entirely from contemporary political documents and often sited as the beginning of the first period of modern documentary drama.<ref name=":1">Dawson, Gary Fisher. ''Documentary Theatre in the United States: An Historical Survey and Analysis of Its Content, Form, and Stagecraft.'' Greenwood Press, 1999, p. 14, 16, 21.</ref> In this and other early works, Piscator sought to depict the "absolute truth"<ref>Piscator, Erwin. ''The Political Theatre.'' Berlin, 1929, p. 65.</ref> and focused on the presentation of factual material in [[Montage (filmmaking)|montage]] and collage form rather than the internal lives of the characters.<ref name=":2">{{cite journal |last1=Mason |first1=Gregory |title=Documentary Drama from the Revue to the Tribunal |journal=Modern Drama |date=1977 |volume=20 |issue=3 |pages=263–278 |doi=10.3138/md.20.3.263}}</ref>
=== Depression-Era America === [[File:WPA Federal Theater Project in New York-Living Newspaper-"AAA Plowed Under" - NARA - 195707.tif|thumb|''AAA Plowed Under'', Federal Theater Project]] Documentary theatre spread west during the 1930s. In [[England]], the form was employed by left-leaning political theatre groups like the [[Unity Theatre, Liverpool|Unity Theatre]], which presented both documentary and historical dramas in order to expose the truths of the common man, frequently combining fiction and reality to achieve truth. Unity Theatre's documentary shows focused on the living newspaper aesthetic of Eastern Europe, although their first piece ''Busmen'' (1938) combined abstract and stylized design aesthetics culled from expressionist and constructivist genres with naturalistic dialogue.<ref>Chambers, Colin. "Unity Theatre and the Embrace of the Real." ''Get Real: Documentary Theatre Past and Present'', edited by Alison Forsyth and Chris Megson, Palgrave MacMillan, 2011, pp. 38-52.</ref>
In the [[United States]], the form was adapted by [[Hallie Flanagan|Hallie Flanagan Davis]] and Morris Watson into the large-scale [[Living Newspaper|Living Newspapers]] of the [[Federal Theatre Project]].<ref>"Living newspaper" ''The Oxford Companion to Theatre and Performance.'' 2010. {{ISBN|9780191727917}}.</ref> Initially conceived as an "animated newsreel," the form evolved into its own theatrical genre, using spectacle and [[vaudeville]] techniques in addition to [[agitprop]] and Piscatorian conventions to tackle issues such as labor, housing, and agriculture.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Nadler |first1=Paul |title=Liberty Censored: Black Living Newspapers of the Federal Theatre Project |journal=African American Review |date=1995 |volume=29 |issue=4 |pages=615–622 |doi=10.2307/3042154}}</ref> Often, they included characters like Little Man and Loudspeaker to stand in and speak for and to the audience during the action, fusing fact with dramatic symbol and clarifying the narrative arc. These plays, like later iterations of documentary theatre, were frequently communally created, often by groups of newspaper writers and theatre artists.<ref>O'Connor, John, and Brown, Lorraine. ''Free, Adult, Uncensored: The Federal Theatre Project.'' Eyre Methuen, 1980, pp. 10-11.</ref> The end of the Federal Theatre Project in 1939 brought documentary theatre in the United States to a halt until the early 1960s.<ref name=":2" />
===Post-War Era and the 1970s=== While the documentary theatre of the 1930s stressed the involvement of the audience, much of the work of the 1960s into the 1970s was influenced by [[Bertolt Brecht]]'s distancing of the audience through aesthetic practices in order to question dominant ideologies.<ref>"Documentary Theatre." ''The Continuum Companion to Twentieth Century Theatre'', 2002.</ref> The work of this era focused more intensely on new or alternative perspectives of historical events by restructuring the documents to raise questions about perceived reality. In Germany, these documentary plays focused mainly on the aftermath of Nazism and genocide.<ref name=":0" /> Many of them used transcripts from tribunals, such as ''In the Matter of J. Robert Oppenheimer'' by Heinar Kippart and [[Peter Weiss]]' ''[[The Investigation (play)|The Investigation]].''<ref name=":2" /> In his "Notes on the Contemporary Theatre," Weiss details 14 components of documentary theatre, stating that "the strength of the documentary theatre resides in its ability to arrange fragments of reality into a usable model," and that the artistic power of the genre comes from a partisan interpretation and presentation of factual material. He also detailed the sources for documentary theatre, including "minutes of proceeding, files, letters, statistical tables, stock-exchange communiques, presentations of balance-sheets of banks and industrial undertakings, official commentaries, speeches, interviews, statements by well-known personalities, press, radio, photo, or film reporting of events and all the other media bearing witness to the present."<ref>Weiss, Peter. "Notizen zum dokumentarischen Theater," ''Rapporte 2'', Frankfurt am Main: Suhrkamp Verlag, 1971.</ref>
This type of documentary drama was exported to [[Israel]] and the [[Middle East]] by [[Nola Chilton]], whose theatre of testimony focused on marginalized groups in the area and later influenced the work of American practitioners.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ben-Zvi |first1=Linda |title=Staging the Other Israel: The Documentary Theatre of Nola Chilton |journal=TDR |date=2006 |volume=50 |issue=3 |pages=42–55 |doi=10.1162/dram.2006.50.3.42}}</ref> During this period of time, however, the American genre became more overtly political with plays such as [[Martin Duberman]]'s ''In White America'', a piece based in Living Newspaper techniques of narration and song, presented by the [[Free Southern Theater|Free Southern Theatre]], a company that sought to make theatre for black audiences in the south.<ref>Bean, Annemarie. "The Free Southern Theater: Mythology and the Moving Between Movements." ''Restaging the Sixties: Radical Theatres and Their Legacies,'' edited by James M. Harding and Cindy Rosenthal, University of Michigan, 2006, pp. 269-285.</ref> Plays also became more experimental, leading to documentary-style performances, as artists like [[Joseph Chaikin]] and [[The Open Theater|The Open theatre]] used historical documents as source material for improvisations (''[[Viet Rock]]'')<ref>Shank, Theodore. ''American Alternative Theater.'' Grove Press Inc., 1982, p. 38.</ref> or [[Luis Valdez]] combining verbatim text from newspapers, transcripts, and correspondence with a fictionalized story and characters in ''[[Zoot Suit (play)|Zoot Suit]]''.<ref>O'Connor, Jacqueline. "Documentary Theatre and ''Zoot Suit''." ''Interrogating America through Theatre and Performance'', Palgrave MacMillan, 2007.</ref>
In England, meanwhile, the use of tape-recorded testimony to generate script became a hallmark of the Stoke Local Documentary Method, developed by [[Peter Cheeseman]].<ref>Paget, Derek. "The 'Broken Tradition' of Documentary Theatre and Its Continued Powers of Endurance." ''Get Real: Documentary Theatre Past and Present'', edited by Alison Forsyth and Chris Megson, Palgrave MacMillan, 2011, pp. 224-236.</ref> In his many plays, including ''Fight for Shelton Bar'' (1977), ''Hands Up, For You the War Is Ended!'' (1971), Cheeseman focused on the exact transcription of recorded interviews, and is one of the earliest pioneers of the sub-genre verbatim theatre. The theories of Cheeseman and other British practitioners of verbatim theatre informed much of American documentary theatre of the late 20th-century.<ref name=":1" />
=== Late 20th-century and early 21st-century === [[File:Laramie Project (15611763903).jpg|thumb|''The Laramie Project'']] The focus on individuals within the context of historical events that permeated the documentary theatre of the 1960s and 1970s paved the way for artist- and individual-centric documentary theatre in the 1980s and 1990s. During this period of time, the focus shifted even further away from broad historical presentations to focus more specifically on how identity shaped personal relationships with major events. The seminal works of this period, which highlight the work of the artist as interpreter of the factual material, include one-person shows such as [[Anna Deavere Smith]]'s ''[[Fires in the Mirror]]'' (1992), collectively created shows like [[Tectonic Theater Project|Tectonic Theatre Project]]'s ''[[The Laramie Project]]'' (2000),<ref name=":3">Odendahl-James, Jules. "A History of U.S. Documentary Theatre in Three Stages." ''American Theatre Magazine'', August 22, 2017. https://www.americantheatre.org/2017/08/22/a-history-of-u-s-documentary-theatre-in-three-stages/</ref> and playwright-driven work like Anne Nelson's ''The Guys'' (2001) and [[Jessica Blank]] and [[Erik Jensen (actor)|Erik Jensen]]'s ''[[The Exonerated (play)|The Exonerated]]'' (2002).<ref>Collins-Hughes, Laura. "The play's the thing: the dramatic and narrative appeal of documentary theater." ''Nieman Reports'', Summer 2015, p. 8. ''Academic OneFile'', <nowiki>http://link.galegroup.com.ez-proxy.brooklyn.cuny.edu:2048/apps/doc/A431081527/AONE?u=cuny_broo39667&sid=AONE&xid=89597130</nowiki>. Accessed 30 Apr. 2018.</ref> In Eastern Europe, new German documentary theatre also focused on the importance of the artist as interpreter through the development of media-driven non-narrative creations of auteur directors like Hans-Werner Kroesinger.<ref name=":0" />
== Contemporary practice == Contemporary documentary theatre is defined by its privileging of subjectivity over universality and questioning of the definition of truth in an age where digital and physical realities collide.<ref>Martin, Carol. "Our Reflection Talks Back." ''American Theatre Magazine'', August 22, 2017, https://www.americantheatre.org/2017/08/22/our-reflection-talks-back/</ref> Many contemporary practitioners reject the term "documentary theatre" in favor of more equivocal labels like "investigative theatre" that allow for more leeway in the artistic interpretation of reality and moves away from the original concept of the artist as moral arbiter of the truth.<ref>Parenteau, Amelia. "How Do You Solve a Problem Like Documentary Theatre?" ''American Theatre Magazine,'' August 22, 2017, https://www.americantheatre.org/2017/08/22/how-do-you-solve-a-problem-like-documentary-theatre/</ref> Just as Piscator utilized the new media of film and projection to enhance his productions, so contemporary documentary theatre continues to rely on new media to explore the increasingly fuzzy line between reality and representation of reality. Similarly, documentary theatre continues to rely on a democratic process of interview gathering and multiple artistic perspectives to create new narratives.<ref name=":3" /> This has led to a proliferation of plays, both verbatim and fictionalized, that focus on the stories of [[Refugee|refugees]] and migrants that use interviews and workshops as the starting point for narrative plays.<ref>Jeffers, Alison. ''Refugees, Theatre and Crisis: Performing Global Identities''. Palgrave MacMillan, 2012, p. 56.</ref>
==Verbatim theatre== '''Verbatim theatre''' is a form of documented theatre in which plays are constructed from the precise words spoken by people interviewed about a particular event or topic.
===Definition=== The playwright interviews people who are connected to the topic that is the play's focus and then uses their testimony to construct the play. In this way, the playwright seeks to present a degree of objectivity akin to that represented by news reporting. Such plays are focused on politics, disasters, sporting and other social events.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
A verbatim (word-for-word) style of theatre uses the real words from interviewees to construct the play. [[Campion Decent]], [[Australia]]n playwright and author of the verbatim theatre play ''Embers'', said it is “not written in a traditional sense… but is... conceived, collected and collated”.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sydneystage.com.au/content/view/214/ |title=Embers |first=Rebecca |last=Whitton |publisher=Sydney Stage Online |date=August 10, 2006}}</ref> it is a creative type of drama to help tell the story of what actually happened. Verbatim theatre exists as conceived in the United Kingdom; whereas, in the United States verbatim theatre is not distinguished and, thus, is lumped into the broader genre that is documentary theatre. Therefore, the plays, movies and TV listed below – as verbatim theatre – authored by playwrights living and writing in the United States should be considered as documentary theatre.
===History=== [[United States of America|American]] actress/playwright [[Anna Deavere Smith]] has been described as a pioneer of verbatim theatre due to two of her one-woman plays in the early 1990s: ''[[Fires in the Mirror]]'' (1992), about the 1991 [[Crown Heights riot]], and ''[[Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992]]'' (1994), about the [[1992 Los Angeles riots]]. For both plays, she conducted interviews with numerous people connected to the events, then fashioned the plays out of the interview transcripts.
High-profile pieces of verbatim theatre include ''[[The Laramie Project]]'' by [[Moises Kaufman]] & [[Tectonic Theater]] and its sequel, ''[[The Laramie Project-Ten Years Later]]'', both about the murder of [[Matthew Shepard]] in Laramie, Wyoming in 1998; ''[[Talking to Terrorists]]'' by [[Robin Soans]], ''[[My Name is Rachel Corrie]]'' by [[Alan Rickman]] and [[Katharine Viner]], ''[[Deep Cut]]'' by [[Philip Ralph]] and Katharine Viner, ''[[The Permanent Way]]'' by [[David Hare (dramatist)|David Hare]] and ''[[Counted]]'' (2010) by [[LookLeftLookRight]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/features/the-rise-of-democratic-theatre-1942833.html |title=The rise of democratic theatre |first=Emily |last=Jupp |publisher=The Independent |date=April 13, 2010}}</ref> Unusually, ''[[London Road (musical)|London Road]]'' (2011) by [[Alecky Blythe]] and [[Adam Cork]], is a verbatim [[musical theatre|musical]], in which the verbatim spoken text is coupled with music composed and sung to resemble the source interviews as closely as possible.
More recent examples of political verbatim theatre are [[Tess Berry-Hart]]'s plays ''Someone To Blame'' (2012) and ''Sochi 2014'' (2014). In ''Someone To Blame'' (about the miscarriage of justice of teenager [[Sam Hallam]] <ref>https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/may/16/sam-hallam-released-seven-years</ref>) the words were taken solely from witness statements, court transcripts, media headlines and interviews with those involved.<ref>http://hackneycitizen.co.uk/2011/03/16/sam-hallam-campaigners-make-drama-of-hoxton-murder-case/</ref> ''Sochi 2014'' was created from interviews with various [[LGBT]] citizens in [[Russia]] after [[Vladimir Putin]]'s anti-gay laws (see [[LGBT rights in Russia]]) in the run up to the [[2014 Winter Olympics]].<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/news/gay-russia-finds-a-voice-in-london-play-8793026.html</ref>
''[[Black Watch (play)|Black Watch]]'' (2006) integrates interviews taken with members of the [[Black Watch]] with dramatized versions of their stories and dance pieces. The piece originated in the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] and was created by the [[National Theatre of Scotland]] and [[Gregory Burke]]. ''[[8 (play)|8]]'', a play by [[Dustin Lance Black]], is an example that uses interviews and courtroom transcripts in order to reenact the legal argument and witness testimony of the ''[[Perry v. Schwarzenegger]]'' case.
Recorded voice delivery is an extension of verbatim theatre in which actors have recorded interviews played back to them during the performance, allowing them to directly mimic the accents and manner of speech, as well as the words, of the people they portray.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} An example is ''[[Grandpa Sol and Lily's Grandma Rosie]]'' by [[Lana Schwarcz]], in which Schwarz portrays the residents of a retirement home via puppetry and playback of interviews via [[iPod]].
In 2012, the Welsh National Theatre put on a play about money problems between the different social classes named ''sgint''. It was the first Welsh-language verbatim play.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://s4c.co.uk/pethe/en/category/documentaries/ |title=Documentaries |publisher=Hafan S4C}}</ref>
In November 2013 and again in 2014, JW3, a Jewish Cultural Centre in Finchley Road, London presented the verbatim play 'Listen, we're Family' by Matthew Lloyd and Kerry Shale. Shale played one of the roles with Debby Chazen, Jennifer Stoller, and Tom Berish.
==Major examples of documentary theatre==
=== Early 20th-century ===
* ''In Spite of Everything'' (1925) * ''One-Third of a Nation'' (1938)
=== Mid 20th-century ===
* ''The Investigation'' (1965) * ''In the Matter of J. Robert Oppenheimer'' (1969)
=== Late 20th- and early 21st-century ===
* ''Fires in the Mirror'' (1992) * ''Gross Indecency'' (1997) * ''The Laramie Project'' (2000) * ''The Guys'' (2001) * ''The Exonerated'' (2002) * ''I Am My Own Wife'' (2003) * ''My Name is Rachel Corrie'' (2005)
=== Contemporary ===
* ''Arguendo'' (2013) * ''Pretty Filthy'' (2015)
==See also== *[[Docudrama]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Documentary Theatre}} [[Category:Theatrical genres]] [[Category:Documentaries|Theatre]] [[Category:Docudrama plays|*]]

An '''Edgeworth price cycle''' is cyclical pattern in prices characterized by an initial jump, which is then followed by a slower decline back towards the initial level. The term was introduced by Maskin and Tirole (1988)<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Maskin|first=Eric|last2=Tirole|first2=Jean|date=1988|title=A Theory of Dynamic Oligopoly, II: Price Competition, Kinked Demand Curves, and Edgeworth Cycles|jstor=1911701|journal=Econometrica|volume=56|issue=3|pages=571–599|doi=10.2307/1911701}}</ref> in a theoretical setting featuring two firms bidding sequentially and where the winner captures the full market.
== Phases of a price cycle ==
A price cycle has the following phases: * War of attrition: When the price is at marginal cost, the firms are engaged in a war of attrition where each firm hopes that the competitor will raise her price first ("relent"). * Jump: When one firm relents, the other firm will then in the next period undercut, which is when the market price jumps. This first period is the most valuable to be the low-price firm, which is what causes firms to want to stay in the war of attrition to force the competitor to jump first. * Undercutting: then follows a sequence where the firms take turns at undercutting each other until the market arrives back in the war of attrition at the low price.
== Discussion ==
It can be debated whether Edgeworth Cycles should be thought of as tacit collusion because it is a Markov Perfect equilibrium, but Maskin and Tirole write: ''"Thus our model can be viewed as a theory of tacit collusion."'' (p. 592).<ref name=":0" />
Edgeworth cycles have been reported in gasoline markets in many countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dictionaryofeconomics.com/article?id=pde2011_E000331|title=Edgeworth price cycles : The New Palgrave Dictionary of Economics|website=www.dictionaryofeconomics.com|access-date=2018-01-02}}</ref> Because the cycles tend to occur frequently, weekly average prices found in government reports will generally mask the cycling. Wang (2012)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wang|first=Zhongmin|date=2009-12-01|title=(Mixed) Strategy in Oligopoly Pricing: Evidence from Gasoline Price Cycles Before and Under a Timing Regulation|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/649801|journal=Journal of Political Economy|volume=117|issue=6|pages=987–1030|doi=10.1086/649801|issn=0022-3808|citeseerx=10.1.1.320.9839}}</ref> emphasizes the role of price commitment in facilitating price cycles: without price commitment, the dynamic game becomes one of simultaneous move and here, the cycles are no longer a Markov Perfect equilibrium but rely on, e.g., supergame arguments.
Edgeworth cycles are distinguished from both [[sticky pricing]] and [[cost-based pricing]]. Sticky prices are typically found in markets with less aggressive price competition, so there are fewer or no cycles. Purely cost-based pricing occurs when retailers mark up from wholesale costs, so costs follow wholesale variations closely.
== Alternative models of price cycles ==
There is a separate literature, which has explored conditions under which price cycles like the ones observed gasoline markets and found that consumer search models can rationalize cycling under various conditions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fershtman|first=Chaim|last2=Fishman|first2=Arthur|date=1992|title=Price Cycles and Booms: Dynamic Search Equilibrium|jstor=2117475|journal=The American Economic Review|volume=82|issue=5|pages=1221–1233}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tappata|first=Mariano|date=2009-12-01|title=Rockets and feathers: Understanding asymmetric pricing|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1756-2171.2009.00084.x/abstract|journal=The RAND Journal of Economics|language=en|volume=40|issue=4|pages=673–687|doi=10.1111/j.1756-2171.2009.00084.x|issn=1756-2171}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lewis|first=Matthew S.|date=2011-06-01|title=Asymmetric Price Adjustment and Consumer Search: An Examination of the Retail Gasoline Market|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1530-9134.2011.00293.x/abstract|journal=Journal of Economics & Management Strategy|language=en|volume=20|issue=2|pages=409–449|doi=10.1111/j.1530-9134.2011.00293.x|issn=1530-9134}}</ref> Here, the intuition is that there is a small subset of consumers that are not informed about prices and therefore will buy from a firm regardless of the price charged. Once prices get low enough, a firm may find it optimal to charge a high price and exploit this small loyal segment rather than trying to win the whole market.
==See also== *[[Sticky pricing]]
==References== <references /> *E., Maskin and Tirole, J., “A Theory of Dynamic Oligopoly II: Price Competition, Kinked Demand Curves and Edgeworth Cycles”, Econometrica 56, 1988. *Eckert, Andrew and West, Douglas S., "Retail Gasoline Price Cycles across Spatially Dispersed Gasoline Stations", Journal of Law and Economics, Vol. XLVII, No. 1, April 2004, p. 245
==External links== *Noel, Michael (2003), [http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1162/rest.89.2.324?journalCode=rest Edgeworth Price Cycles, Cost-based Pricing and Sticky Pricing in Retail Gasoline Markets] *Noel, Michael (2004), [http://repositories.cdlib.org/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1020&context=ucsdecon Edgeworth Price Cycles: Evidence from the Toronto Retail Gasoline Market]
[[Category:Game theory]]

revision.comment: /* top */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: December of 2001 → December 2001 (3)
revision.text:
The '''Fantasma Magic''' company (also known as '''Fantasma Toys''') was co-founded in December 2001{{where|date=February 2018}} by Roger Dreyer and [[Mark Setteducati]].<ref name="Ring2003">{{cite journal|last1=Stratman|first1=Mike|date=June 2003|title=Dreyer And Setteducati: Fantasma Founders|url=https://askalexander.org/display/10906/Linking+Ring/47|journal=[[The Linking Ring]]|volume=83|issue=6|pages=47–49, 84|subscription=yes|via=}}</ref> Fantasma Magic is a manufacturer of magic tricks, magic sets, science-based toys and [[Rubik's]] items as well as other novelties. Fantasma Magic supplies magic tricks, specialty magic sets and other toys to retailers such as [[Costco]], [[Toys R Us]],<ref name="Ioannou 2010">{{cite journal|last1=Ioannou|first1=Lori|title=Tricks To Keep Growing|journal=Time Magazine|date=March 22, 2010|volume=175|issue=11|page=70}}</ref> [[K-mart]], [[Walmart]], [[Target Corporation|Target]] and others.<ref name="Swiss 2007">{{cite journal|last1=Swiss|first1=Amadeo|title=Fantasma: The New Wave In Magic|journal=Street Magic Magazine|date=December 2007|volume=1|issue=5|page=84}}</ref>
The first iteration of the Fantasma company was formed by Roger Dreyer in 1987 as a manufacturer of [[hologram]]s. This led to Fantasma manufacturing clocks and watches for [[Disney]]. In 1999, [[Foster Grant]] purchased the company.<ref name="Ring2003" />
In 2001, after a stint with [[Marvin's Magic]], Dreyer partnered with Setteducati, an inventor and consultant with [[Tenyo]] and creator of [[Milton Bradley]]'s Magic Works line, to form Fantasma Magic. In February 2003, Fantasma Magic became the exclusive magic supplier to the [[FAO Schwarz]] flagship store in NYC and remained their exclusive magic supplier until FAO Schwarz closed their flagship store in July 2015.<ref name="Ring2003" />
In spring of 2006, Fantasma Magic left their offices at the [[International Toy Center]] when it was revealed the Center had been sold. Fantasma opened its first retail location on the corner of 7th Avenue and 33rd Street. The store featured magic tricks and sets from Fantasma Magic as well as amateur and professional magic effects from a variety of other manufacturers. The store also housed the first [[Houdini Museum of New York]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lombardi|first1=Nancy|title=A Serendipitous Turn Of Events|journal=Toys & Family Entertainment|date=June 2006|page=42}}</ref> The store and museum have since moved to 213 West 35th Street, Rm 401, New York, NY.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hull|first1=Sarah|title=The Rough Guide to New York City|date=February 1, 2016|publisher=Rough Guides|location=London, England|isbn=9780241258439|page=170}}</ref>
As of 2010, Fantasma Magic reported profits of $950,000 on $10 million in sales.<ref name="Ioannou 2010" /> Fantasma Magic is the only magic manufacturer to receive the unpaid endorsement of the [[International Brotherhood of Magicians]]. Fantasma Magic has founded and sponsors their own I.B.M. Ring (Ring 257) in [[Las Vegas]], Nevada.<ref name="Swiss 2007" />
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Magic shops]] [[Category:American companies established in 2001]] [[Category:Companies based in New York City]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{infobox theatre festival | theatre_festival_name = Festival of monodrama and mime | image = | caption = | location = [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]] | selector = Milovan Zdravković | editor_in_chief = Radomir Putnik | founded = 1973 | founders = Ljubiša Ružić, [[Ognjenka Milićević]] | dates = June, July | playtype = | website = [http://www.festmono-pan.org.rs/ Official website] }}
'''Festival of monodrama and mime''' is a theatre festival dedicated to [[mime]]s and [[monodrama]]s. It is held annually near the end of June or the first week in July in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]], and it's traditionally held within the Puppet Theatre "Pinocchio". Festival of Monodrama and Mime participants are awarded in five different categories: best monodrama, best mime, most successful participant, an award for ingenuity, and the Audience's award.<ref>{{cite web|title=Архив фестивала|url=http://www.festmono-pan.org.rs/arhiva|work=festmono-pan.org.rs|publisher=Фестивал монодраме и пантомиме|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=41st Festival of Monodrama and Mime|url=http://www.belgradian.com/what-s-on/festivals/9801-41st-festival-of-monodrama-and-mime/|accessdate=16 December 2016|agency=Belgradian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Kocic|first1=Petar|title=Minister Petkovic to open The 38th Monodrama and Mime Festival|agency=InSerbia|date=5 July 2013}}</ref>
== Festival leadership == Following the decision of the Municipal Assembly of [[Zemun]], in 2015 new members of the Council and Director of the festival were appointed. [[Predrag Miletić]], an actor of the National Theatre, was chosen as Head of the Festival. Radomir Putnik, Rada Đuričin, Igor Bojović, Rastko Janković, Stevan Rodić and Stanivuk Vanja were chosen as members. Borislav Balać was appointed as Festival director, and Milovan Zdravković was selected as Selector of the festival. The editors of the festival are Radomir Putnik and Tadija Miletić.<ref>{{cite web|title=FESTIVAL PROGRAM COUNCIL|url=http://www.festmono-pan.org.rs/en/|website=Festival monodrame i pantomime|accessdate=22 March 2017}}</ref>
== Festivаl publications == In addition to the regular annual program booklet, the festival has published six books from several authors:<ref>{{cite web|title=Festivаlske publiаkcije|url=http://www.festmono-pan.org.rs/publikacije|work=festmono-pan.org.rs|publisher=Festivаl monodrаme i pаntomime|accessdate=22 March 2017}}</ref>
* ''Antologijа savremene monodrаme'', Rаdomir Putnik * ''Pаnorаmа monodrаmа'', Rаdomir Putnik * ''Pozorišne i televizijske monodrаme'', Rаdomir Putnik * ''Moje monodrаme'', Rаdа Đuričin * ''Sаmi sa publikom'', Mirjаnа Ojdаnić * ''Zemunskа pozorjа'', Alojz Ujes
== See also == * [[Ognjenka Milićević]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.festmono-pan.org.rs/ Official presentation]
[[Category:Theatre festivals in Serbia]] [[Category:Monodrama]] [[Category:Pantomime]] [[Category:Mime]] [[Category:Summer events in Serbia]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2017}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:filmportal.de}} '''filmportal.de''' is an online database of information related to [[Cinema of Germany|German film]]. It includes extensive information on films and filmmakers as well as articles on film issues. The website was released on occasion of the 54th [[Berlin International Film Festival]] on 11 February 2005. ''filmportal.de'' was revised and expanded in 2011/2012.
== Content == The database provides information on about 85 000 German cinema and television films (as of June 2015) from 1895 to the present. About 8 000 films are presented in detail with content descriptions, stills and/or posters. In addition, ''filmportal.de'' catalogues about 190 000 names of filmmakers, 5 000 of these entries feature a biography.
The lexical information is supplemented by trailers, film clips from German classics, and, increasingly, full-length films. Moreover, editorial texts link the information with the history of film in the [[Weimar Republic]], [[Nazi Germany]] and the [[East Germany|GDR]].
== Organising institutions == ''filmportal.de'' was established by ''[[Deutsches Filminstitut]]'' (Frankfurt) in collaboration with ''CineGraph - Hamburg Center for Research on Film'' and with support of the other members of the German ''Kinematheksverbund'' and the associations of the German film industry. The website is cooperating with the [[Association of European Film Archives and Cinematheques]] (ACE), [[Arte]], ''DEFA Foundation'', [[Goethe-Institut]], ''German Films Service + Marketing GmbH'', [[Deutsche Filmakademie]] and [[Berlin International Film Festival]].
== References == {{reflist}}
* ''Kino'' (May 2005) D. Holloway Issues 78-90:cxxviii * ''The Hollywood Reporter'' (2006) Volume 393:92
==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.filmportal.de/}}
[[Category:Film websites]] [[Category:Television websites]] [[Category:Online film databases]] [[Category:Online encyclopedias]] [[Category:Cinema of Germany]]

revision.text:
{{Expand Japanese|からくり|date=December 2011}} {{Refimprove|date=February 2008}}[[Image:KarakuriBritishMuseum.jpg|thumb|200px|A karakuri automaton, circa 1800. [[British Museum]].]] [[Image:TeaAutomatAndMechanism.jpg|thumb|200px|Tea-serving karakuri, with mechanism, 19th century. [[National Museum of Nature and Science]], [[Tokyo]].]] [[Image:Tokugawaendashizoroe1.JPG|thumb|200px|Dashi karakuri of the ''Tsutsui-chō/Dekimachi tennōsai'' in [[Nagoya]].]] {{nihongo|'''Karakuri puppets'''|からくり人形|karakuri ningyō}} are traditional [[Japan]]ese mechanized [[puppet]]s or [[automata]], originally made from the 17th century to 19th century. The dolls' gestures provided a form of entertainment. The word ''karakuri'' means "mechanisms" or "trick".<ref>Jane Marie Law, ''Puppets of Nostalgia – The Life, Death and Rebirth of the Japanese [[Awaji Ningyō-Jōruri|Awaji Ningyo]] Tradition'', 1997, Princeton University Press, {{ISBN|978-0-691-02894-1}}</ref> It is used to describe any device that evokes a sense of awe through concealment of its inner workings.<ref>Shea, Michael (2015). [http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1162/LEON_a_00936#.VZ0zyabfjsY "Karakuri: Subtle Trickery in Device Art and Robotics Demonstrations at Miraikan"] ''Leonardo'' 48(1): 40-47.</ref>
Three main types of karakuri exist. {{nihongo3|stage karakuri|舞台からくり|Butai karakuri}} were used in [[theatre]]. {{nihongo3|tatami room karakuri|座敷からくり|Zashiki karakuri}} were small and used in homes. {{nihongo3|festival car karakuri|山車からくり|Dashi karakuri}} were used in religious festivals, where the puppets were used to perform reenactments of traditional [[mythology|myth]]s and [[legend]]s.
They influenced the [[Noh]], [[Kabuki]] and [[Bunraku]] theatre.
''Karakuri'' is alternatively written in Japanese [[kanji]] as {{nihongo2|絡繰り}}, {{nihongo2|絡繰}}, {{nihongo2|機巧}}, {{nihongo2|機関}}, and archaically as {{nihongo2|唐繰}}.
==Zashiki karakuri== The most common example today of a zashiki karakuri mechanism is a tea-serving robot, which starts moving forward when a cup of tea is placed on the plate in its hands. It was used in a situation when a host wanted to treat a guest in a recreational way. It moves in a straight line for a set distance, moving its feet as if walking, and then bows its head. This signals that the tea is for drinking, and the doll stops when the cup is removed. When it is replaced, the robot raises its head, turns around and returns to where it came from. It is typically powered by a wound spring made of whalebone, and the actions are controlled by a set of cams and levers.
== Gallery == <gallery> File:Tokugawaendashizoroe5.JPG|Dashi karakuri of the ''Tsutsui-chō/Dekimachi tennōsai'' in [[Nagoya]]. File:Tokugawaendashizoroe6.JPG| File:Tokugawaendashizoroe8.JPG| File:Shimohanda festival1.jpg|''Shimohanda Festival'' in [[Handa, Aichi|Handa]] </gallery>
==See also==
*[[Animatronic]] *[[Gakutensoku]] *[[Japanese robotics]] *[[Tanaka Hisashige]] *[[Automaton]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Karakuri}} *[http://www.karakuri.info/ Karakuri.info] English information site * [http://cgi2.nhk.or.jp/michi/cgi/detail.cgi?dasID=D0004200010_00000 Karakuri puppets in Takayama Matsuri Festival][[NHK]](video) {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Karakuri ningyo}} [[Category:Puppets]] [[Category:Science and technology during the Edo period]] [[Category:Performing arts in Japan]] [[Category:Japanese dolls]] [[Category:Japanese inventions]] [[Category:Historical robots]] [[Category:Robots of Japan]] [[Category:17th-century robots]] [[Category:Entertainment robots]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Lou Pearlman | image = Lou-pearlman-mugshot.jpg | caption = 2007 arrest mugshot | birth_name = Louis Jay Pearlman | alias = {{plainlist| *Big Poppa<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,990118-2,00.html|title=Big Poppa's Bubble Gum Machine|last=Roche|first=Timothy|last2=Handy|first2=Bruce|date=February 1, 1999|work=Time Magazine|accessdate=April 9, 2009}}</ref> *Incognito Johnson<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2007-06-18-lou-pearlman_N.htm|title=Lou Pearlman appears at hearing in Guam|last=Handy |first=Bruce|date=June 18, 2007|work=USA Today| accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref> }} | birth_date = {{birth date|1954|6|19}} | birth_place = [[Flushing, New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|8|19|1954|6|19}} | death_place = [[Miami]], Florida, U.S. | resting_place = [[New Montefiore Cemetery]] | family,_First_Cousin = [[Art Garfunkel]] | criminal_charge = * [[conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]] * [[money laundering]] * [[making false statements]]<ref name="msnbc">{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/23473811/|title=Boy band founder to plead guilty in $300M suit|last= |first=|date=March 4, 2008|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=April 9, 2009}}</ref> | criminal_penalty = 25 years in prison | criminal_status = Deceased | module = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes | background = non_performing_personnel | genre = [[Dance-pop]] | occupation = Record producer, manager | years_active = 1993–2006 | label_name = Trans Continental Records | associated_acts = {{plainlist| *[[Backstreet Boys]] *[[NSYNC]] *[[O-Town]] *[[Lyte Funky Ones|LFO]] *[[Take 5 (band)|Take 5]] *[[Natural (band)|Natural]] *[[US5]] *[[Jordan Knight]] *[[Aaron Carter]] *[[Smilez and Southstar]] *[[C-Note (band)|C-Note]] *[[Innosense]] *[[Olive Carpet]] }} }} }} '''Louis Jay Pearlman''' (June 19, 1954 – August 19, 2016) was an American record producer and fraudster. He was the manager of successful 1990s [[boy band]]s such as [[Backstreet Boys]] and [[NSYNC]]. In 2006, he was accused of running one of the largest and longest-running [[Ponzi scheme]]s in history, leaving more than $300 million in debts. After being apprehended, he pleaded guilty to [[conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]], [[money laundering]], and [[making false statements]] during a [[bankruptcy]] proceeding. In 2008, Pearlman was convicted and sentenced to up to 25 years in prison.<ref name="msnbc"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSN2139523420080521|title=Boy band mogul Pearlman sentenced to 25 years|last=Liston |first=Barbara|date=May 21, 2008|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=April 9, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/specials/2008/reports/lou-pearlman/index.shtml|title=Special report: Unraveling a transcontinental fraud|last=Huntley|first=Helen|date=|publisher=tampabay.com|accessdate=April 9, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090608052006/http://www.tampabay.com/specials/2008/reports/lou-pearlman/index.shtml|archivedate=June 8, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orange/orl-pearlmansg,0,2411340.storygallery|title=More coverage of the Lou Pearlman saga|last=|first=|date=|work=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=April 9, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223033008/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orange/orl-pearlmansg,0,2411340.storygallery|archivedate=December 23, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He died in federal custody in 2016.
==Early life== Pearlman was born and raised in [[Flushing, New York]], the only child of [[Jews|Jewish]] parents, Hy Pearlman, who ran a dry cleaning business, and Reenie Pearlman, a school lunchroom aide. He was a first cousin of musician [[Art Garfunkel]]. His home at Mitchell Gardens Apartments was located across from [[Flushing Airport]], where he and childhood friend Alan Gross would watch [[blimp]]s take off and land. According to his autobiography, which he titled ''Bands, Brands, & Billions'', it was during this period that he used his position on his school newspaper to earn credentials and get his first ride in a blimp. This is disputed by Gross, who claims he was the school reporter, and allowed Pearlman to tag along.<ref name="St. Petersburg Times">[http://www.sptimes.com/2007/10/21/Business/In_humble_Queens__Lou.shtml St. Petersburg Times] By Helen Huntley, October 21, 2007 ''In humble Queens, Lou Pearlman was king''</ref><ref name="Mad About Boys">{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2007/11/pearlman200711|title=Mad About the Boys|first=Vanity Fair|last=Magazine|publisher=}}</ref>
His cousin Garfunkel's fame and wealth helped fire Pearlman's own interest in the music business. As a teenager he managed a band, but when success in music proved elusive, he turned his attention to [[aviation]]. During his first year as a student at [[Queens College]], Pearlman wrote a [[business plan]] for a class project based on the idea of a [[helicopter]] taxi service in [[New York City]]. By the late 1970s, he had launched the business based on his business plan, starting with one helicopter.{{sfn|Henderson|2006|loc=p. 174}} He persuaded German businessman Theodor Wüllenkemper to train him on blimps and subsequently spent some time at Wüllenkemper's facilities in Germany learning about the airships.
==Suspicions of insurance fraud and pump & dump== Returning to the [[United States]], Pearlman formed Airship Enterprises Ltd, which leased a blimp to [[Jordache]] before actually owning one. He used the funds from Jordache to construct a blimp, which promptly crashed. The two parties sued each other, and seven years later Pearlman was awarded $2.5 million in damages. On the advice of a friend, Pearlman started a new company, Airship International, taking it [[Initial public offering|public]] to raise the $3 million he needed to purchase a blimp, claiming (falsely) that he had a partnership with Wüllenkemper. He leased the blimp to [[McDonald's]] for advertising.<ref name="St. Petersburg Times"/><ref name="Mad About Boys"/>
He then relocated Airship International to [[Orlando, Florida]] in July 1991, where he signed [[MetLife]] and [[SeaWorld]] as clients for his blimps. Airship International suffered when one of its clients left and three of the aircraft crashed. The company's stock, which had once been pumped up to $6 a share, dropped to a price of 3 cents a share, and the company was shut down:<ref name=roddyboyd>[http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/orl-lou0107apr01,0,6354571.story Orlando Sentinel] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071005155302/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/orl-lou0107apr01,0,6354571.story |date=October 5, 2007 }} April 1, 2007 ''A world out of sync''</ref><ref>[http://www.nypost.com/seven/02222007/business/boy_band_kingpins_penny_roots_showing_business_roddy_boyd.htm ''New York Post''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070224105436/http://www.nypost.com/seven/02222007/business/boy_band_kingpins_penny_roots_showing_business_roddy_boyd.htm |date=February 24, 2007 }} February 22, 2007 ''BOY BAND KINGPIN'S PENNY ROOTS SHOWING''</ref> {{quote|After he took his air charter company, Airship International, public in 1985, Pearlman became personally and professionally close to Jerome Rosen, a partner at small-cap trading outfit Norbay Securities. Based in Bayside, Queens, and frequently in trouble with regulators, Norbay actively traded Airship stock. This sent Airship's stock price consistently higher, enabling Pearlman to sell hundreds of thousands of shares and warrants at ever-higher prices. However, Airship was reporting little revenue, cash flow or net income. In return for keeping his [[penny stock]] liquid, Pearlman allegedly paid Rosen handsome commissions, according to a mutual friend, that reached into 'the tens of thousands of dollars' per trade.}}
==Entertainment industry career== Pearlman became fascinated with the success of the [[New Kids on the Block]], who had made hundreds of millions of dollars in record, tour and merchandise sales. He started Trans Continental Records with the intent of mimicking their boy-band business model. The [[record label|label]]'s first band, the [[Backstreet Boys]], consisted of five unknown performers selected by Pearlman in a $3 million talent search.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Gray|first=Tyler|title=The Fat Man Sings|publisher=''[[Radar Online|Radar]]''|date=October 7, 2007|page=91}}</ref> Management duties were assigned to a former New Kids on the Block manager, [[Johnny Wright (music manager)|Johnny Wright]], and his wife Donna.<ref>[http://www.sptimes.com/News/102300/Floridian/The_starmaker.shtml St. Petersburg Times] The starmaker</ref> The Backstreet Boys became the [[Boy band#Best-selling boy bands|best-selling boy band of all time]], with record sales of 130 million,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/art/2010/02/143_61233.html|title=Backstreet Boys Share Secrets to Success|last=Garcia|first=Cathy Rose A.|work=[[The Korea Times]]|date=February 22, 2010|accessdate=January 24, 2011}}</ref> hitting [[List of music recording sales certifications|gold, platinum, and diamond]] in 45 different countries. Pearlman and the Wright then repeated this formula almost exactly with the band [[*NSYNC]], which sold over 70 million records globally.
With these two major successes under his belt, Pearlman had become a music [[Business magnate|mogul]]. Other boy bands managed by Pearlman were [[O-Town]] (created during the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]–[[MTV]] reality TV series ''[[Making the Band]]''), [[Lyte Funky Ones|LFO]], [[Take 5 (band)|Take 5]], [[Natural (band)|Natural]] and [[US5]], as well as the girl group [[Innosense]] (with [[Britney Spears]] in the very beginning as a short-term member), co-managed with Lynn Harless (the mother of [[*NSYNC]] band member [[Justin Timberlake]]). Other artists on the Trans Continental label included [[Aaron Carter]], [[Jordan Knight]], [[Smilez & Southstar]] and [[C Note (band)|C-Note]]. Pearlman also owned a large entertainment complex in Orlando, including a recording studio he called Trans Continental Studios, and a dance studio by [[Disney World]] named "O-Town."<ref name="roddyboyd"/> In 2002, Pearlman and Wes Smith co-wrote ''Bands, Brands and Billions: My Top 10 Rules for Making Any Business Go Platinum.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2007-04-01/news/LOU01_1_lou-pearlman-youtube-fame|title=A World Out Of Sync|publisher=}}</ref>
Lou Pearlman also was an officer at [[Tag Entertainment|TAG Entertainment]]. This [[independent film]] company produced some low-budget, yet profitable, movies, and DVDs.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}
===Band lawsuits=== With the exception of US5, all of the musical acts who worked with Pearlman sued him in [[United States federal courts|Federal Court]] for misrepresentation and [[fraud]]. All cases against Pearlman have either been won by those who have brought lawsuits against him, or have been settled out of court.
The members of Backstreet Boys were the first to file a lawsuit against Pearlman, feeling that their contract—under which Pearlman collected as both manager and producer—was unfair, since Pearlman was also paid as a sixth member of the Backstreet Boys (i.e., one-sixth of the band's own income). The band's dissatisfaction began when member [[Brian Littrell]] hired a lawyer to determine why the group had received only $300,000 for all of their work, while Pearlman and his record company had made millions. Fellow boy band *NSYNC was having similar issues with Pearlman, and its members soon followed suit.<ref name="Mad About Boys"/>
At the age of 14, pop star [[Aaron Carter]] filed a lawsuit in 2002 that accused Pearlman and Trans Continental Records of cheating him out of hundreds of thousands of dollars and of racketeering in a deliberate pattern of criminal activity. This suit was later settled out of court.<ref>[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/128667221.html?FMT=FT&FMTS=FT&PMID=33031&desc=Lawsuit:+Pop+star's+manager+a+racketeer+Series:+2b ''St. Petersburg Times''] June 25, 2002. Lawsuit: Pop star's manager a racketeer {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070219063301/https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/128667221.html?FMT=FT&FMTS=FT&PMID=33031&desc=Lawsuit:+Pop+star's+manager+a+racketeer+Series:+2b |date=February 19, 2007 }}</ref>
===Talent scouting scandal=== In September 2002, Pearlman purchased Mark Tolner's internet-based talent company, ''Options Talent Group'' f/k/a ''Sector Communications,'' which had previously named ''Emodel'' and ''Studio 58'' and would then go through several names including ''Trans Continental Talent,'' ''TCT,'' ''Wilhelmina Scouting Network'' or ''WSN,'' ''Web Style Network,'' ''Fashion Rock'', and ''Talent Rock.'' Regardless of the name, all incarnations were based on the business model used by Emodel founder [[Ayman "Alec" Difrawi]] (aka Alec Defrawy), himself a convicted con-man,<ref>[http://www.secinfo.com/dRqWm.315z6.htm SEC Info Trans Continental Entertainment Group Inc – 8-K For 10/7/02] ''The SEC about the nature of the business relations between Trans Continental and Ayman "Alec" Difrawi, Ralph Edward Bell, [[Cortes Wesley Randell]] and Jason Hoffman, the felony records of Difrawi and Randell, and the FTC sanctions against Bell and Hoffman.''</ref> who played a principal role in running Options / TCT / WSN<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2003-10-05/news/0310050128_1_lou-pearlman-scouting-network-wilhelmina-scouting|title=Scouting Network's History Troubles Pearlman|last=Barker |first=Tim|date=October 5, 2003|work=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=October 20, 2010}}</ref> and setting up Fashion Rock. The companies received unfavorable press attention, ranging from questions about their business practices to outright declarations that they were scams.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.browardpalmbeach.com/2001-09-06/news/hustling-for-models/|title=Hustling for Models|last=Olson |first=Wyatt|date=September 6, 2001|publisher=New Times Broward-Palm Beach|accessdate=April 8, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://pqarchiver.nypost.com/nypost/access/102908194.html?dids=102908194:102908194&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jan+26%2C+2002&author=LAUREN+BARACK&pub=New+York+Post&edition=&startpage=019&desc=MANNEQUIN+MESS+TOP+AGENCIES+DENY+CONNECTION+TO+EMODEL |title=MANNEQUIN MESS TOP AGENCIES DENY CONNECTION TO EMODEL |last=Barack |first=Lauren |date=January 26, 2002 |work=New York Post |accessdate=April 8, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714223208/http://pqarchiver.nypost.com/nypost/access/102908194.html?dids=102908194%3A102908194&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS%3AFT&date=Jan%2B26%2C%2B2002&author=LAUREN%2BBARACK&pub=New%2BYork%2BPost&edition=&startpage=019&desc=MANNEQUIN%2BMESS%2BTOP%2BAGENCIES%2BDENY%2BCONNECTION%2BTO%2BEMODEL |archivedate=July 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pilotonline.com/business/bz0128mod.html |title=Cashing in on dreams of glamour |last=Kimberlin |first=Joanne |date=January 28, 2002 |publisher=pilotonline.com |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020204111656/http://www.pilotonline.com/business/bz0128mod.html |archivedate=February 4, 2002 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ksat.com/news/1231335/detail.html |title=Is eModel Golden Opportunity Or Big Business? |last= |first= |date=February 12, 2002 |publisher=Ksat.com |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720163255/http://www.ksat.com/news/1231335/detail.html |archivedate=July 20, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://fox5atlanta.com/iteam/options.html |title=Options Talent Group: An I-Team Investigation|last=Reed|first=Travis|date=May 13, 2002|publisher=Fox Atlanta|accessdate=April 8, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051107213650/http://fox5atlanta.com/iteam/options.html |archivedate = November 7, 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.komotv.com/news/archive/4068126.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061213003332/http://www.komotv.com/news/archive/4068126.html|archivedate=December 13, 2006|title=Buyer Beware: Ever Thought About Being A Model?|last=Thompson|first=Connie|date=August 13, 2002|publisher=Komo News|accessdate=April 8, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://fox5atlanta.com/iteam/tct.html |title=Trans Continental Talent |last=Reed |first=Travis |date=November 14, 2002 |publisher=Fox Atlanta |accessdate=April 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051029062558/http://fox5atlanta.com/iteam/tct.html |archivedate=October 29, 2005 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.clickondetroit.com/news/1789200/detail.html |title=Hidden Cameras Expose Talent Agency Scam |last= |first= |date=November 15, 2002 |publisher=ClickOnDetroit.com |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060512173808/http://www.clickondetroit.com/news/1789200/detail.html |archivedate=May 12, 2006 }}</ref><ref>I Am Not A Model, Jane Magazine, March 2003</ref>
After [[Hotjobs]] and [[Monster.com]] pulled over a thousand of the company's job ads from their boards,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/58517/page/1|title=Model Misbehavior|last=Braiker|first=Brian|date=July 18, 2003|publisher=Newsweek|accessdate=April 8, 2009}}</ref> they were further advertised on the Difrawi-founded<ref>[http://domains.adrforum.com/domains/decisions/1060670.htm National Arbitration Forum] Decision – Industry Publications LLC v. Industry magazine</ref> "Industry Magazine" website. The [[Better Business Bureau]]'s opinion about Options / TCT / WSN was negative, citing a "pattern of complaints concerning misrepresentation in selling practices."<ref>[http://www.bbb.org/central-florida/business-reviews/advertising-agencies-and-counselors/web-style-network-in-orlando-fl-38000155 BBB Orlando] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123131118/http://www.bbb.org/central-florida/business-reviews/advertising-agencies-and-counselors/web-style-network-in-orlando-fl-38000155 |date=November 23, 2010 }} report on Web Style Network a/k/a Options Talent, TC Talent, Trans Continental Talent, Wilhelmina Scouting Network, Wilhelmina Scouts, WSN. ''Quote: "Based on BBB files, this company has an unsatisfactory record with the BBB due to a pattern of complaints concerning misrepresentation in selling practices"''</ref> The [[New York (state)|New York]] State [[Consumer Protection]] Board issued an alert, naming it the largest example they had found of a [[Photo Mill|photo mill scam]]<ref>"Model Agency Labeled A Scam" PageSix, New York Post, October 20, 2003</ref> (in which agencies force models to shoot portfolios with photographers on their own payrolls), and a state senator called it trying "to make a quick, dishonest dollar."<ref>[http://www.nassaucountyny.gov/agencies/oca/NewsRelease/2003/04012003.html Office of Consumer Affairs] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905174533/http://www.nassaucountyny.gov/agencies/OCA/NewsRelease/2003/04012003.html |date=September 5, 2008 }} Wilhelmina Scouting Network, Modeling Agency</ref>
The [[San Francisco]] labor commissioner declared it in violation of California law, and several state agencies were reported to be investigating it.<ref>"Modeling Agency- Big Fees, Small Return," KRON-4 San Francisco, February 18, 2003.</ref> In Florida, around 2,000 complaints were filed with the then-[[Attorney General]] [[Charlie Crist]] and the Better Business Bureau, and an investigation was started by Assistant AG Dowd. However, no charges were filed, as the newly appointed Assistant AG MacGregor was unable to find "any substantial violations" and the company had declared bankruptcy, "leaving no deep pockets to collect damages from."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.local10.com/news/3558774/detail.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 27, 2007 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927044723/http://www.local10.com/news/3558774/detail.html |archivedate=September 27, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tolner.com/docs/2006_02_03_10_27_41.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=February 25, 2007 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070225144226/http://www.tolner.com/docs/2006_02_03_10_27_41.pdf |archivedate=February 25, 2007 }}, PDF document: John MacGregor providing status of the Options Talent investigation</ref>
By June 2004, Fashion Rock, LLC had filed a civil suit for defamation against some who had criticized Pearlman's talent businesses. The case was dismissed and closed in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orlandoweekly.com/orlando/pearlmans-jihad/Content?oid=2259942|title=Pearlman's jihad|first=Jeffrey C.|last=Billman|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://myclerk.myorangeclerk.com/default.aspx Clerk Circuit Court Orange County Florida] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130710035100/http://myclerk.myorangeclerk.com/default.aspx |date=July 10, 2013 }}, search case number 2004-CA-004844-O</ref> One of the accused, [[Canadians|Canadian]] consumer-fraud expert [[Les Henderson]], successfully pursued a [[libel]] [[lawsuit]] against Pearlman, Tolner, El-Difrawi and several others.<ref>[http://www.canlii.org/en/on/onsc/doc/2006/2006canlii32908/2006canlii32908.html CanLII] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109054005/http://www.canlii.org/en/on/onsc/doc/2006/2006canlii32908/2006canlii32908.html |date=January 9, 2016 }} Court File No. C-8937-05, Henderson v. Pearlman, Tolner, Difrawi a.o., 2006 Ontario Superior Court of Justice</ref><ref>[http://www.nypost.com/seven/09242006/business/louie_wasnt_n_sync_business_tim_arango.htm New York Post September 24, 2006] LOUIE WASN'T 'N SYNC / LAWSUIT BACKFIRES "LOU Pearlman picked the wrong guy to sue" {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223064044/http://www.nypost.com/seven/09242006/business/louie_wasnt_n_sync_business_tim_arango.htm |date=December 23, 2008 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.canlii.org/en/on/onsc/doc/2009/2009canlii43641/2009canlii43641.html CanLII – 2009/08/18] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204163639/http://www.canlii.org/en/on/onsc/doc/2009/2009canlii43641/2009canlii43641.html |date=February 4, 2012 }} Court File No. C-8937-05 – ''Henderson v. Pearlman'' a.o., a case in the Ontario Superior Court of Justice</ref>
Fashion Rock, LLC lived on until February 2, 2007,<ref>[http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orange/orl-pearlman0207feb02,0,5838668.story?coll=orl-home-headlines Orlando Sentinel] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315004434/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orange/orl-pearlman0207feb02,0,5838668.story?coll=orl-home-headlines |date=March 15, 2008 }} February 2, 2007 ''Pearlman hit with another huge suit''</ref><ref>[http://blogs.tampabay.com/money/2007/02/state_say_trans.html St. Petersburg Times Blog: Money Talk] February 9, 2007 ''State shuts down Fashion Rock'' {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070207071434/http://blogs.tampabay.com/money/2007/02/state_say_trans.html |date=February 7, 2007 }}</ref> when its assets were sold in Pearlman's bankruptcy proceeding.<ref>[http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/orl-pearlman2407mar24,0,1638411.story?coll=orl-business-headlines Orlando Sentinel] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014042756/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/orl-pearlman2407mar24,0,1638411.story?coll=orl-business-headlines |date=October 14, 2007 }} March 24, 2007 ''Pearlman's talent-scout company sold''</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orlando.bbb.org/codbrep.html?ID=38000274|title=BBB of Central Florida, Inc.|publisher=}}</ref> Difrawi continued filing lawsuits that all got [[WOT: Web of Trust#Lawsuit|dismissed]] and was most recently running Expand, Inc. dba Softrock.org aka Employer Network, from the same address as former TCT.
== Ponzi scheme == In 2006, investigators discovered Pearlman had perpetrated a long-running Ponzi scheme that defrauded investors out of more than $300 million. For more than 20 years, Pearlman had enticed individuals and banks to invest in Trans Continental Airlines Travel Services Inc. and Trans Continental Airlines Inc., both of which existed only on paper.<ref>[http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/flm/pr/2008/March/20080304_Pearlman_Orl_FraudPleaAgg.pdf USDOJ press release March 4, 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080911093914/http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/flm/pr/2008/March/20080304_Pearlman_Orl_FraudPleaAgg.pdf |date=September 11, 2008 }} LOU PEARLMAN SIGNS PLEA AGREEMENT THAT INCLUDES ADDITIONAL CHARGES THAT HE DEFRAUDED INVESTORS</ref> Pearlman used [[Forgery|falsified]] [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation]], [[AIG]] and [[Lloyd's of London]] documents to win investors' confidence in his "Employee Investment Savings Account" program, and he used fake financial statements created by the fictitious accounting firm Cohen and Siegel to secure bank loans.<ref name="Mad About Boys"/>
===Investigation=== In February 2007, Florida regulators announced that Pearlman's Trans Continental Savings Program was indeed a massive fraud, and the state took possession of the company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wftv.com/news/10915811/detail.html |publisher=wftv.com |date=February 2, 2007 |title=State Takes Over Lou Pearlman's Embattled Orlando Company |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205041540/http://www.wftv.com/news/10915811/detail.html |archivedate=February 5, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Most of the at least $95 million which was collected from investors was gone. Orange County Circuit Judge Renee Roche ordered Pearlman and two of his associates, Robert Fischetti and Michael Crudelle, to bring back to the United States "any assets taken abroad which were derived from illegal transactions."<ref>{{cite web|title=State: Trans Continental Savings Program a Fraud|url=http://blogs.tampabay.com/money/2007/02/state_say_trans.html|accessdate=June 29, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080302010032/http://blogs.tampabay.com/money/2007/02/state_say_trans.html|archivedate=March 2, 2008|date=February 2, 2007}}</ref>
Following a flight from officials over the course of which he had been reported seen in Israel and Germany, Pearlman was arrested in [[Indonesia]] on June 14, 2007 after being spotted by a [[Germany|German]] tourist couple.<ref>[http://www.cfnews13.com/News/Local/2007/6/14/lou_pearlman_taken_into_custody_in_indonesia.html Lou Pearlman Taken Into Custody In Indonesia] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100101042618/http://www.cfnews13.com/News/Local/2007/6/14/lou_pearlman_taken_into_custody_in_indonesia.html |date=January 1, 2010 }}</ref> He was living in a tourist hotel in [[Nusa Dua]] in [[Bali]]. Pearlman had been seen in Orlando in late January 2007, in early February in Germany, including an appearance on German television on February 1. Reportedly he was also seen in Russia, Belarus, Israel, Spain, Panama, and Brazil. In early February, an attorney in Florida received a letter from Pearlman sent from Bali.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://columbustelegram.com/news/boy-band-mogul-expelled-from-indonesia-in-fbi-custody/article_579af6aa-cef7-593d-9715-f256d88e2045.html|title=Boy-band mogul expelled from Indonesia, in FBI custody|first=Pedro Ruz Gutierrez, Scott Powers and Sara K. Clarke/The Orlando|last=Sentinel|publisher=}}</ref> Pearlman was then indicted by a federal grand jury on June 27, 2007.<ref>[http://www.tampabays10.com/news/local/crime/article.aspx?storyid=57854 Tampa Bay's WTSP 10 News] ''Pearlman indicted on fraud charges''</ref> Specifically, Pearlman was charged with three counts of [[bank fraud]], one count of [[mail fraud]] and one count of [[wire fraud]].
===Conviction and sentencing=== Five days before his sentencing, Pearlman requested a telephone and an Internet connection two days a week to continue to promote bands. [[United States District Judge|U. S. District Judge]] [[G. Kendall Sharp]] rejected the request.<ref name="hrep">{{cite web|last1=Abramovitch|first1=Seth|title=Boy Band Mogul Lou Pearlman's Prison Interview: My Ponzi Scheme Was Smarter Than Madoff’s|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/backstreet-boys-lou-pearlmans-prison-672724|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=August 20, 2016}}</ref> On May 21, 2008, Sharp sentenced Pearlman to 25 years in prison on charges of conspiracy, money laundering, and making false statements during a bankruptcy proceeding. Pearlman could reduce his prison time by one month for every million dollars he helped a bankruptcy trustee recover. He also ordered individual investors to be paid before institutions in distributing any eventual assets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/23473811/|title=Boy band founder to plead guilty in $300M suit|date=March 5, 2008|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSN2139523420080521 Reuters] Boy band mogul Pearlman sentenced to 25 years</ref>
===Bankruptcy=== Pearlman and his companies were forced into involuntary bankruptcy in March 2007.<ref name="tbay1">{{cite web|last1=Huntley|first1=Helen|title=Lou Pearlman gets 25 years in scam, time off for loot|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/business/lou-pearlman-gets-25-years-in-scam-time-off-for-loot/517402|website=Tampa Bay Times|accessdate=August 21, 2016}}</ref> Trustees and lenders auctioned off Pearlman's assets and personal belongings through [[eBay]] and a traditional bankruptcy auction.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Johnston|first1=Maura|title=If You Want A Piece Of Lou Pearlman, You Can Find One On EBay {{!}} Idolator|url=http://www.idolator.com/362273/if-you-want-a-piece-of-lou-pearlman-you-can-find-one-on-ebay|website=Idolator|accessdate=August 21, 2016|date=February 29, 2008}}</ref><ref name="WaPo1">{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=Travis|title=Boy-Band Loot Sold at Bankruptcy Auction|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/12/AR2007061200604.html|website=The Washington Post|accessdate=August 21, 2016|date=June 12, 2007}}</ref> [[Church Street Station (Orlando)|Church Street Station]], a historic train station in downtown Orlando which Pearlman had purchased in 2002, was sold at a bankruptcy auction in April 2007 for $34 million.<ref name="tbay1"/> Several of Pearlman's belongings, including his college degrees, were purchased by ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' journalist and film critic [[Nathan Rabin]] during the eBay auction.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rabin|first1=Nathan|title=Why Do I Own This?: Lou Pearlman 20th Century Republican Leader Certificate|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/lou-pearlman-20th-century-republican-leader-certif-31115|website=The A.V. Club|accessdate=August 21, 2016|date=July 31, 2009}}</ref>
==Molestation allegations==
In 2007, ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' magazine published an article "Mad About The Boys"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2007/11/pearlman200711|title=Mad About the Boys|last=Burrough|first=Bryan|access-date=2016-08-21|work=Vanity Fair}}</ref> detailing extensive allegations that Pearlman molested some of his charges. Pearlman publicly addressed the allegations in a 2014 prison interview with ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' magazine, claiming they were unsubstantiated, and that he had never been accused of such by anyone he had helped succeed. ''Vanity Fair'', Pearlman claimed, had only interviewed "people that had a grudge."<ref name="hrep"/> ''The Hollywood Reporter'' noted Pearlman's "well-documented track record of robbing his artists blind" and rumours of his predilection for "buff, blond boys in his entourage", while a ten-year relationship with a former nurse, Tammie Hilton, remained unconsummated. "He was very religious," Hilton said.<ref name="hrep"/> However, in a 2009 interview with [[Howard Stern]], the former lead singer of band [[LFO (American band)|LFO]], [[Rich Cronin]], said that he had only received a fraction of the money owed to him from record sales, and claimed that Pearlman had "wanted to bang everyone", and had attempted to seduce him multiple times. Cronin also alleged that those who did oblige Pearlman were looked after.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.howardstern.com/show/2009/1/21/rich-cronin-got-pennies-RundownGalleryModel-6545/|title=Rich Cronin of LFO Visits|website=Howard Stern|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref>
Cronin's assertions were not necessarily backed by fellow band members. Brad Fischetti, who continued to refer to Lou Pearlman as a friend, expressed sadness at the news of his arrest, imprisonment, and death.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Brad Fischetti Comments On Former Manager Lou Pearlman’s Arrest|journal=popdirt.com|url=http://popdirt.com/tag/brad-fischetti/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Fischetti|title=God rest your soul Lou Pearlman|url=https://twitter.com/bradfischetti/status/767179643690557440|agency=Twitter}}</ref> As of late November 2011, [[Nick Carter (musician)|Nick Carter]] had not confirmed his mother's statements regarding Pearlman, and in a later interview, when asked if true, he chose his words carefully when he spoke, but he seemed to hint that bitterness might be a motivating factor for the sexual gossip.<ref>{{cite news|title=Backstreet Boys Open Up To John Norris About Disgraced Boy-Band Mogul Lou Pearlman: 'Karma's Karma'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1573182/backstreet-boys-open-up-john-norris-about-lou-pearlman.jhtml|newspaper=MTV|date=October 2007}}</ref> In an interview conducted by the Orlando ''Sentinel,'' openly gay former *[[NSYNC]] member [[Lance Bass]], when asked about the ''Vanity Fair'' article, stated that Pearlman had never behaved inappropriately with them.<ref>{{cite news|last=Abott|first=Jim|title=Lance Bass book comes out|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2007-10-23/news/bass23_1_lance-bass-justin-timberlake-stage-door|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date=Oct 2007}}</ref>
==Death== In 2008, Pearlman began his prison sentence with a projected release date of March 24, 2029. However, he suffered a [[stroke]] in 2010 while incarcerated.<ref name="hrep"/> Pearlman died, while still in custody at the [[Federal Correctional Institution, Miami|Federal Correctional Institution]] in [[Miami]], Florida, on August 19, 2016, from [[cardiac arrest]], that followed an infection of the interline of the heart valve. Pearlman had surgery to replace a heart valve a few weeks before his death. The prison took him to a hospital where he was scheduled for another surgery and he ultimately died. He was buried ten days later on August 29, 2016 in the family burial area. He was 62 years old.<ref>{{cite web|title=Inmate Locator|url=https://www.bop.gov/inmateloc/|website=Federal Bureau of Prisons|accessdate=August 20, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Liam |last=Stackaug |title=Lou Pearlman, Svengali Behind Backstreet Boys and ’NSync, Dies at 62 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/23/arts/music/lou-pearlman-dead.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=August 22, 2016 |access-date=August 23, 2016}}</ref>

[[Bryan Burrough]], interviewed for the episode, noted of this last that he had not expected to hear about sexual improprieties, and ascribed the lack of willingness to come forward about them to Pearlman's repeated usage of the tactic of veiled threats to intimidate those who would have otherwise done so. * {{IMDb name|0669117}}

[[Kenny "Dope" Gonzalez]] | past_members = [[Todd Terry]] }} '''Masters at Work''' is the [[garage house]] production and [[remix]] team of [[Little Louie Vega|"Little" Louie Vega]] and [[Kenny "Dope" Gonzalez]]. ==Biography== They first worked together using the name in 1990. Gonzalez had initially given the name to mutual friend [[Todd Terry]], who recorded several tracks under that name during the 1980s. The duo has produced music together under the names MAW, KenLou, Sole Fusion, Hardrive, and Nuyorican Soul. The latter moniker came about in 1993, blending their residence in [[New York City]], heritage from [[Puerto Rico]], and affinity for [[soul music]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.residentadvisor.net/dj/maw/biography|title=RA: Masters At Work|last=Advisor|first=Resident|website=Resident Advisor|access-date=2017-08-23}} Their Nuyorican Soul project had the duo working extensively with real (as opposed to [[sampling (music)|sampled]] or [[Sound synthesis|synthesized]]) musicians, in a variety of styles including [[Latin American music|Latin]], [[disco]], [[jazz]], and more. Musicians who took part in this project include [[Vincent Montana Jr.]], [[Roy Ayers]], [[George Benson]], [[Jocelyn Brown]], [[Tito Puente]], and members of the [[Salsoul Orchestra]]. The self-titled album released under the name Nuyorican Soul in 1996 included original tracks as well as cover versions of songs by the performers with which the duo was working, such as "Sweet Tears" (Roy Ayers), and "[[Runaway (Nuyorican Soul song)|Runaway]]", originally sung by [[Loleatta Holloway]] with the Salsoul Orchestra, here sung by [[La India|India]] and featuring musicians from the original recording of 1977. MAW has a history as remixers, having reproduced tracks for various acts both inside and outside the world of dance music. Some of the artists remixed by the two producers include [[Michael Jackson]], [[Janet Jackson]]. [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Donna Summer]], [[Aaliyah]], [[Gus Gus]], [[Jody Watley]], [[Jamiroquai]], [[Earth Wind & Fire]], and [[Stephanie Mills]]. == Charted singles == As of 2017, Masters at Work [[Single (music)|singles]] have reached the [[Dance Club Songs|''Billboard'' Dance Club Songs]] [[Record chart|chart]] on four occasions. {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |+ List of singles as lead artist showing year released and chart position: ! rowspan="3" scope="col" style="width:22em;" | Title ! rowspan="3" scope="col" | Year !
