{{Infobox Network |network_name = Національна суспільна телерадіокомпанія України
(National Public Broadcasting Company of Ukraine) |network_logo = [[File:UA PBC logo.svg|250px]] |country = Ukraine |network_type = [[Terrestrial television|Broadcast]] [[radio]] and [[television]],
[[Website|online]] and [[printing]] |headquarters = [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]] |available = National; International |owner = [[State Committee in Television and Radio-broadcasting (Ukraine)|State Committee in Television and Radio-broadcasting]] |key_people = Zurab Alasania (chairman) |launch_date = {{start date and age|2015|4|8|df=y}} |founder = [[Cabinet of Ukraine|Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]] |slogan = |motto = |past_names = State Tele-Radiobroadcasting Company (DTRK) |website = [http://suspilne.media/ Official site] }} '''National Public Broadcasting Company of Ukraine''' ('''UA:PBC'''; {{lang-uk|Національна суспільна телерадіокомпанія України}}, ''Natsionalna Suspilna Teleradiokompaniya Ukrayiny'') is the national public broadcaster in [[Ukraine]]. As such it was registered on 19 January 2017.[https://www.ebu.ch/news/2017/01/ebu-welcomes-new-public-broadcaster-in-ukraine EBU WELCOMES NEW PUBLIC BROADCASTER IN UKRAINE], [[EBU]] (20 Jan 2017)
{{uk icon}} [http://pda.pravda.com.ua/news/id_7132884/ The state registered a "public broadcaster"], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (19 January 2017) In its revamped form the company provides content for its three television and [[Radio Ukraine|radio channels]].[http://m.day.kyiv.ua/en/article/day-after-day/public-broadcasting-company-has-been-launched-ukraine The Public Broadcasting Company has been launched in Ukraine], [[Den (newspaper)|Den]] (8 April 2015) From 1995 until its current name the television predecessor of the current broadcaster was named the '''National Television Company of Ukraine''' ('''NTU'''; {{lang-uk|Національна Телекомпанія України}}, ''Natsionalna Telekompaniya Ukrayiny''). [[Radio Ukraine]] was its radio predecessor and a stand-alone company until it merged with NTU to be the first public broadcasting company of Ukraine. Radio broadcasts in Ukraine, at the time [[Ukrainian SSR|part of the]] [[USSR]], began in [[Kharkiv]] in 1924, and a nationwide radio network was initiated in 1928.{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Media" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=365|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&pg=PA365&lpg=PA365&dq=1924+radio+Ukraine&source=bl&ots=FpiDaQq4OD&sig=XNEVl-CkiG_ACYEs2g1PJ29T_Vo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjs3J6RtZTSAhWCKMAKHc8yC3UQ6AEIHDAB#v=onepage&q=1924%20radio%20Ukraine&f=false}} (In the first years of the USSR Kharkiv was the capital of Ukraine, from December 1919 to January 1934, after which the capital relocated to [[Kiev]].{{cite book|first=George|last=Liber|title=Soviet Nationality Policy, Urban Growth, and Identity Change in the Ukrainian SSR, 1923-1934|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2oqThmrFCfwC&pg=PA160|year=1992|publisher=Cambridge University Press}}) In 1965 the first nationwide Ukrainian television channel ''Ukraiinske Telebachennia'' or ''UT'' (‘Ukrainian Television’) was established.[https://www.academia.edu/28548193/Where_Broadcast_and_Digital_Cultures_Collide_A_Case_Study_of_Public_Service_Media_in_Ukraine Where Broadcast and Digital Cultures Collide: A Case Study of Public Service Media in Ukraine] by [[Mariia Terentieva]], [[academia.edu]] (1 June 2016) (Ukraine was part of the USSR from 1920 until [[Declaration of Independence of Ukraine|it declared its independence on 24 August 1991]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=BNUtdVrw6lIC&pg=PA722&dq=16+July+1991+Ukrainian+state+sovereignty.&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=ejEVUc-7G-Xa0QX4-4HgBg&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=16%20July%201991%20Ukrainian%20state%20sovereignty.&f=false A History of Ukraine: The Land and Its Peoples] by [[Paul Robert Magocsi]], [[University of Toronto Press]], 2010, {{ISBN|1442610212}} (page 563/564 & 722/723)) == Overview == It is a public join-stock agency with 100% of its shares belonging to the state, and operates the television channel [[UA:Pershyi]], the only Ukrainian TV channel that has a coverage over 97% of Ukraine's territory and is the only state-owned national channel. Its programs are oriented at all social layers of the Ukrainian society and [[Demographics of Ukraine|national minorities]]. Among priority directions of the network are informative publicism, popular scientific, culturologic, entertaining and sport-oriented ones. According to the viewer's rating the First Channel significantly trails all of his more recent privately held rivals. It was planned that the National Television Company of Ukraine (NTCU) will be changed to Public Television Network in 2009. The government will lose its direct control over the national network. The Public Television Network will contain of several channels, such as, "First Channel", "Second Channel", "Euronews Ukraine" and "Ukraine and the World". But not until 2014 a new law was passed to make the network an independent, public broadcaster.[https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/ukraine-press-state-broadcaster-television-politicians-oligarchs-a7452586.html Ukraine is on the brink of media freedom, but oligarchs are set to put a stop to it], [[independent.co.uk]] (2 December 2016) With the creation of this National Public Broadcasting Company of Ukraine in 2015 the [[National Radio Company]] of Ukraine merged into this new company.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/259522.html Poroshenko signs law on public broadcasting company], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 April 2015) It, (renamed) the ''National Public Broadcasting Company of Ukraine'', was registered on 19 January 2017. == Television == Currently UA:PBC broadcasting these TV channels: === Nationwide === *'''[[UA:First]]''' *'''[[Kultura (Ukrainian television channel)|UA:Kultura]]''' === UA:Regional (Regional channels of the UA:PBC network)=== *'''UA:Krym''' (Autonomous Republic of Crimea){{cite web|title=UA:Krym Official Website|url=http://uakrym.com}} *'''UA:Cherkasy''' (formerly Ros) (Cherkasy Oblast){{cite web|title=Ros Official Website|url=http://rosmedia.com.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Chernihiv''' (formerly Siver) (Chernihiv Oblast){{cite web|title=UA:Chernihiv Official Website|url=http://chodtrk.com.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Bukovyna''' (formerly Bukovyna) (Chernivtsi Oblast){{cite web|title=Bukovyna Official Website|url=https://bukovyna.tv|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Donbass''' (formerly DoTB in Donetsk Oblast and LOT in Luhansk Oblast) (Donetsk and Luhansk Oblast){{cite web|title=UA:Donbass Official Website|url=https://www.uadonbas.com/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''51''' (Dnipropetrovsk Oblast){{cite web|title=51 Official Website|url=http://www.51.dp.ua|language=Ukrainian|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180308164300/http://www.51.dp.ua/ |archive-date=8 March 2018}} *'''UA:Karpaty''' (formerly Karpaty) (Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast){{cite web|title=UA:Karpaty Official Website|url=http://new.trk.if.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Kharkiv''' (formerly OTB) (Kharkiv Oblast){{cite web|title=UA:Kharkiv Official Website|url=https://otb.com.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''Skifiya''' (Kherson Oblast){{cite web|title=Skifiya Official Website|url=http://skifija.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''Podillya-Centr''' (Khmelnytskyi Oblast){{cite web|title=Podillya-Centr Official Website|url=http://www.odtrk.km.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''Centralnyi Kanal''' (Kiev and Kiev Oblast){{cite web|title=Official Website|url=http://central.suspilne.media/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''Kirovohrad''' (Kirovohrad Oblast){{cite web|title=Kirovohrad Official Website|url=http://tv.kr.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Lviv''' (formerly TRC Lviv) (Lviv Oblast){{cite web|title=UA:Lviv Official Website|url=http://www.lviv.tv/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''Mykolaiv''' (Mykolaiv Oblast){{cite web|title=Mykolaiv Official Website|url=http://mtrk.tv/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Odessa''' (formerly ODT) (Odessa Oblast){{cite web|title=ODT Official Website|url=http://oodtrk.od.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''Ltava''' (Poltava Oblast){{cite web|title=Ltava Official Website|url=http://www.ltava.poltava.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Rivne''' (formerly RTB) (Rivne Oblast){{cite web|title=UA:Rivne Official Website|url=http://rtb.rv.ua|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Sumy''' (Sumy Oblast){{cite web|title=UA:Sumy Official Website|url=http://tv.sumy.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''TTB''' (Ternopil Oblast){{cite web|title=TTB Official Website|url=http://todtrk.te.ua|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Vinntysa''' (formerly Vintera) (Vinnytsia Oblast){{cite web|title=UA:Vinntysa Official Website|url=https://vintera.com.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Volyn''' (formerly Nova Volyn) (Volyn Oblast){{cite web|title=Nova Volyn Official Website|url=http://voltv.com.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Zakarpattia''' (formerly Tysa-1) (Zakarpattia Oblast){{cite web|title=Tysa-1 Official Website|url=http://tysa1.tv/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''Zaporizhia''' (Zaporizhia Oblast){{cite web|title=Zaporizhia Official Website|url=http://zp.nrcu.gov.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} *'''UA:Zhytomyr''' (formerly Zhytomyr) (Zhytomyr Oblast){{cite web|title=UA:Zhytomyr Official Website|url=http://tvradiozt.com.ua/|language=Ukrainian}} == Radio == {{For|more information|Radio Ukraine}} Currently UA:PBC broadcasting four radio channels: *'''UA:Ukrainian radio''' *'''UA:Radio revision.comment: Added hatnote indicating real hardware exists (painful when debugging device drivers)
revision.text:
{{About|the fictional computer memory|the actual hardware and applications|Write-only memory (engineering)}} '''Write-only memory''' ('''WOM''') is the opposite of [[read-only memory]] (ROM). By some definitions, a WOM is a memory device which can be written but never read. Initially there seemed to be no practical use for a memory circuit from which data could not be retrieved. The concept is still often used as a [[joke]] or a [[euphemism]] for a failed memory device.
The first use of the term is generally attributed to [[Signetics]] in 1972. Signetics published some ''write-only memory'' literature as the result of an inside practical joke, which is frequently referenced within the electronics industry,<ref name="origin">{{cite web | url = http://portal.national.com/rap/Story/WOMorigin.html | title = The origin of the WOM – the "Write Only Memory" | first = Robert A | last = Pease | author-link = Bob Pease | publisher = National Semiconductor | accessdate = 2011-11-28 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6AxYMnQNI?url=http://portal.national.com/rap/Story/WOMorigin.html | archivedate = 26 September 2012 | deadurl = yes | df = }}.</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/2011-04/02/content_12268630.htm | title = Are you fooled? | work = China Daily | date = 2011-04-02 | accessdate = 2011-11-28}} </ref> a staple of software engineering lexicons,<ref name = Jargon>{{cite web | archiveurl = http://www.retrologic.com/jargon/W/write-only-memory.html | accessdate = 2011-11-28 | archivedate = 24 November 2006 | url = http://www.catb.org/~esr/jargon/html/W/write-only-memory.html | title =write-only memory|work = The [[Jargon File]] | publisher = CatB | editor-link = Eric S. Raymond | editor-last = Raymond | editor-first = Eric S}}</ref> and included in collections of the best hoaxes.
==Signetics== The datasheet was created "as a lark"<ref>{{Citation |url = http://www.sigwom.com/?page_id=17 |title = Sigwom}}.</ref> by Signetics engineer John G 'Jack' Curtis<ref name = Sigwom>{{Citation |url = http://www.sigwom.com/ |title = Sigwom }}.</ref> and was inspired by a fictitious and humorous vacuum tube datasheet<ref>''Wemac 1Z2Z Slightly Tentative Data'', Eitel-McCullough, Inc. 1953, itself a successor to ''Umac 606 Infernal Anode Phantasatron Data Sheet'', Eitel-McCullough, Inc., 1950, both referenced on [http://www.sigwom.com/?p=186 "Wemac 1Z2Z Data Sheet", sigwom.com]. Note the reference to 'encabulitzation' in the 1Z2Z data sheet.</ref> from the 1940s. It was seen as "an icebreaker" and was deliberately included in the Signetics catalog.<ref name = Sigwom />
Roy L Twitty, a Signetics PR person, released a tongue-in-cheek press release touting the WOM on April 1, 1973.<ref>{{Citation |url= http://www.ariplex.com/tina/tsignet1.htm |editor = Tina |title = Funny pages |contribution = The original papers on the invention of the best electro… }}</ref>
Instead of the more conventional characteristic curves, the 25120 "fully encoded, 9046×N, Random Access, write-only-memory" data sheet included meaningless diagrams of "bit capacity vs. Temp.", "Iff vs. Vff", "Number of pins remaining vs. number of socket insertions", and "[[Acceptable quality limit|AQL]] vs. selling price". The 25120 required a 6.3 VAC V<sub>ff</sub> ([[vacuum tube]] filament) supply, a +10 V<sub>cc</sub> (double the V<sub>cc</sub> of standard [[Transistor-transistor logic|TTL]] logic of the day), and V<sub>dd</sub> of 0±2% volt (i.e. ground). It was specified to run between 0 and −70°C.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Signetics |url=http://www.national.com/rap/files/datasheet.pdf |title=Signetics 25120 Fully Encoded, 9046xN, Random Access Write-Only-Memory |first=John G ‘Jack’ |last=Curtis |year=1972 |accessdate=2012-03-16 |type=photocopy |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316141638/http://www.national.com/rap/files/datasheet.pdf |archivedate=March 16, 2012 }}.</ref>
==Apple== In 1982, [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] published their official ''Apple IIe Reference Manual'' (part number A2L2005),<ref>{{Citation |url = https://archive.org/details/a2_reference_manual |title = Apple IIe Reference Manual |publisher = Apple Computer |year = 1982 |id = part number A2L2005}}, 266 pp.</ref> which included two references to write-only memory:
On page 233: * ''[[bit bucket]]:'' The final resting place of all information; see ''write-only memory''.
On page 250: * ''write-only memory:'' A form of computer memory into which information can be stored but never, ever retrieved, developed under government contract in 1975 by Professor Homberg T. Farnsfarfle. Farnsfarfle's original prototype, approximately one inch on each side, has so far been used to store more than 100 trillion words of surplus federal information. Farnsfarfle's critics have denounced his project as a six-million-[[dollar]] boondoggle, but his defenders point out that this excess information would have cost more than 250 [[billion]] dollars to store in conventional media.
==Book== In 1995 ''[[Computer Contradictionary]]'' book, it reports EWOM, or Erasable Write-Only Memory (an analogy of [[EPROM]]), a memory copyrighted by IBM (Irish Business Machines), which allows the data to be written into and then erased from, for memory re-use.<ref>{{Citation |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=tZKCZje8178C&pg=PA69 |title = EWOM |format = Google books |page = 69 |isbn = 9780262611121 |author1 = Kelly-Bootle |first1 = Stan |year = 1995}}.</ref>
With the explosive growth of the amount of video data available both online and in private use, there emerged a common joke that [[video tape]]s and other video media are "write only memory", because without efficient means of search and retrieval for video data archives, very little is viewed after recording.<ref>{{Citation |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=dRn5-nSYMwwC&pg=PA49 |title = Advances in Visual Information Systems: 4th International Conference, VISUAL. |format = Google books |page = 49 |isbn = 9783540411772 |author1 = Laurini |first1 = Robert |date = 2000-10-18}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Fqk-eKrlFHkC&pg=PA61 |title =Forensic Digital Imaging and Photography |first1 = Herbert L |last1 = Blitzer |first2 = Jack |last2 = Jacobia |format = Google books |page = 61 |isbn =9780121064112 |year =2002}}.</ref>
==Other members of the family==
The 25120 WOM joined a family of equally-useless parts made before and since. These include the dark bulb, dark-emitting diode, WAS gate, and Inoperational Amplifier.<ref>https://www.edn.com/electronics-products/electronic-product-reviews/reader-s-choice-2015/4439097/Zener-enhanced-Dark-Emitting-Diodes--ZeDEDs--deliver-10X-more-Dark-Flux-Watt</ref> Grandparents were the Umac 606 Infernal Anode Phantasatron and the Electrovoice Rearaxial Softspeaker.<ref>http://www.tubecollectors.org/archives/606.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://steamer.mindfart.com/|title=Electro-Voice SP13.5RBXWK Rearaxial Softspeaker|website=steamer.mindfart.com}}</ref> Note that the [[Phantastron]] (not Phantasatron) is a real, if obsolete, circuit for generating precision sawtooth waves.
==See also== *[[/dev/null]] *[[FINO]]—First In, Never Out scheduling algorithm *[[Turboencabulator]] *[[Write-only language]]
